sen.j: 和敬清寂（わけいせいじゃく）とは、茶道において強調されている標語で、特に千家では千利休の定めた「四規」として重要視している。
sen.e: "和敬清寂" (literally means harmony, respect, purity and tranquility) is a slogan emphasized in Sado (Japanese tea ceremony), which is particularly respected in the Senke school of tea ceremony as "Shiki"(Four Principles of Tea) provided by SEN no Rikyu

"和敬清寂" (literally meaning harmony, respect, purity and tranquility) is a slogan emphasized in Sado (Japanese tea ceremony), which is particularly respected in the Senke school of tea ceremony through the "Shiki"(Four Principles of Tea) as laid down by SEN no Rikyu.

Wakei Seijaku (literally meaning harmony, respect, purity and tranquility) is a slogan emphasized in Sado (Japanese tea ceremony), which is particularly respected in the House of Sen through the 'Shiki' (Four Principles of Tea) as laid down by SEN no Rikyu.

sen.j: しかし利休と同時代の確かな資料には見られないことから、学術的には利休の言葉としては認められていない。
sen.e: This slogan, however, is not academically accepted as a word of Rikyu, because there is no description about it in the credible material compiled in the same period with Rikyu.

This slogan, however, is not academically accepted as being directly attributable to Rikyu, because there is no description about it in any credible material compiled in the period contemporaneous with Rikyu.

sen.j: 近年の町田忠三氏の研究「『南方録』成立背景と利休虚像の誕生」（『茶の湯文化学』9号所収／2004）では、「和敬清寂」という言葉を作ったのが大徳寺273世の大心義統（1657－1730）であるという可能性を検討している。
sen.e: The recent study of Chuzo MACHIDA, ""南方録"成立背景と利休虚像の誕生" (the background of establishment of "the Nanpo-roku (the secret book of Rikyu) and the birth of the Rikyu myth) reported in "茶の湯文化学 No.9, 2004" (Chanoyu Bunka-Gaku (the study of the culture of tea ceremony)) No.9, 2004), is pursuing the possibility that the slogan of "和敬清寂" was provided by Daishin Gito (1657-1730), the 273rd chief priest of Daitoku-ji Temple.

The recent study by Chuzo MACHIDA, ""南方録"成立背景と利休虚像の誕生" (The Background of the Establishment of the Nanpo-roku (the Secret Book of Rikyu) and the Birth of the Rikyu Myth) reported in "茶の湯文化学 No.9, 2004" (Chanoyu Bunka-Gaku (The Study of the Culture of Tea Ceremony) No.9, 2004), pursues the possibility that the term "和敬清寂" should be attributed to Daishin Gito (1657-1730), the 273rd chief priest of Daitoku-ji Temple.

The recent study by Chuzo MACHIDA, 'The Background of the Establishment of the Nanpo-roku (the Secret Book of Rikyu) and the Birth of the Rikyu Myth' (reported in "No.9 of Chanoyu Bunka-Gaku (The Study of the Culture of Tea Ceremony), 2004), pursues the possibility that the term 'Wakei Seijaku' should be attributed to Daishin Gito (1657 - 1730), the 273rd chief priest of Daitoku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 注意： 「和敬清寂」という四字熟語は、「和敬静寂」と書かれることが多いが、この「静」の字は誤り。
sen.e: Annotation: The four-Chinese characters idiom "和敬清寂" is often wrongly written as "和敬静寂".
Note: The four-Chinese character idiom "和敬清寂" is often mistakenly written as "和敬静寂".
Note: The four-Chinese character idiom Wakei Seijaku (和敬清寂) is often mistakenly written as 和敬静寂.
